question: In application security, what does normalization help prevent?
choices: Malicious input using different data representations
Session timeouts during login
Excessive CPU usage during queries
Database index corruption
Credential reuse by administrators

question: What is the most critical factor when selecting a biometric system?
choices: Storage requirements
Accuracy
Speed
Enrollment time
User acceptability

question: What is the main goal of input validation in application security?
choices: Increase application throughput and data size
Allow flexible user data formats
Facilitate faster user form completion
Prevent malformed data from compromising applications
Improve database replication efficiency

question: Which component ensures that redundant network links do not create loops?
choices: Dynamic Host Configuration Protocol
Network Time Protocol
Spanning Tree Protocol
Border Gateway Protocol
Domain Name System

question: What best describes the Zero Trust model?
choices: Trust is granted based on prior authentication only
Only administrators are excluded from monitoring
No user or device is automatically trusted
External users are trusted once verified
Trust depends on firewall zones alone

question: What is the role of a demilitarized zone (DMZ)?
choices: Store internal database backups
Monitor VLAN traffic between routers
Host private internal DNS servers
Isolate internal networks from untrusted external networks
Encrypt wireless communications

question: Which is a correct example of a secure file transfer protocol?
choices: SNMP
HTTP
FTPS
FTP
POP3

question: Why must privileged accounts be tightly managed?
choices: They are used only for guest operations
They cannot perform configuration changes
They lack audit and logging capabilities
They store no sensitive credentials
They provide broad control and high risk if misused

question: Why is multi-factor authentication more secure?
choices: It uses more than one type of verification
It hides user identity from the system
It removes passwords completely
It guarantees no account lockouts
It replaces encryption and hashing

question: What is the effect of an account lockout policy?
choices: It blocks accounts that remain idle for days
It deletes passwords after each session
It allows only local device sign-ins
It locks users after repeated failed logins
It changes group policy without notice

question: Which are the three pillars of Zero Trust?
choices: Users, Servers, Storage
Identity, Devices, Defense
Authentication, Authorization, Accounting
Workforce, Workloads, Workplace
People, Processes, Policy

question: What is a key risk in federated identity management?
choices: A breach in one domain can affect others
Users must maintain multiple credentials
It cannot link any external accounts
It blocks all single sign-on capabilities
It requires physical device pairing every session

question: What do Network Access Control (NAC) systems enforce?
choices: Malware sandboxing for attachments
Local user activity on file systems
Access policies for users and devices
Encryption for all outgoing emails
Password reuse prevention rules

question: What happens when data is copied to another volume?
choices: It keeps the same access rights as before
It inherits new permissions from destination
It is removed from all previous logs
It becomes unmodifiable until reviewed
It is automatically encrypted at rest

question: What is the main purpose of an Access Control List (ACL)?
choices: To filter packets based on information in the packet header
To increase network bandwidth by compressing data
To encrypt network traffic at the router interface
To provide end-to-end user authentication
To dynamically reroute packets for redundancy

question: What does a wildcard mask bit value of 0 indicate?
choices: Match only when subnetting is disabled
Match the corresponding bit in the address
Match only if it is a network bit
Perform a binary AND with all bits ignored
Ignore the bit during matching

question: Which command creates a named standard IPv4 ACL?
choices: ip access-list standard ACL_NAME
access-group standard create ACL
ip filter standard 100 name ACL
access-list 10 permit any
ip route add standard ACL

question: What is the implicit rule at the end of every ACL?
choices: forward unprocessed packets
permit all traffic
deny only broadcast traffic
log all remaining packets
deny any

question: Why are named ACLs preferred over numbered ACLs?
choices: They are faster to process in the router hardware
They are easier to manage and identify their purpose
They automatically apply to all router interfaces
They consume less configuration memory space
They are compatible with legacy IOS versions

question: What is a common use of ACLs in mitigating spoofing attacks?
choices: Encrypting all inbound packets from the internet
Using dynamic NAT to rewrite spoofed headers
Blocking packets with invalid or reserved source IP addresses
Filtering out all TCP segments with the RST flag set
Allowing only packets with source port numbers above 1024

question: What is the best placement for an extended ACL?
choices: On the final router before the destination
As far from the traffic source as feasible
On both WAN and LAN interfaces simultaneously
As close to the source as possible
On the core switch for global filtering

question: Why is the 'deny all by default' policy preferred?
choices: It disables all intrusion detection temporarily
It limits access to only necessary services
It applies open routing between private networks
It lets any trusted device bypass filtering rules
It enhances network speed by skipping inspection

question: What is a primary advantage of layered defense?
choices: It eliminates the need for separate authentication servers
It provides automatic redundancy and load balancing
It replaces encryption and monitoring mechanisms
Multiple firewalls add depth against threats
It ensures zero latency between network segments

question: In a two-interface firewall, which traffic is normally allowed?
choices: Traffic crossing from external hosts to DMZs
Public connections directed to internal systems
Multicast routing updates from the Internet
Private network traffic to the public network
Broadcast packets sent from any subnet

question: Why is a demilitarized zone (DMZ) used in design?
choices: To enforce symmetric encryption between routers
To isolate public services from the private network
To merge all internal networks for faster routing
To disable outside access entirely by default
To centralize user identity management systems

question: Which type of DMZ traffic is normally blocked?
choices: Private-to-public management updates
Public-to-DMZ file sharing sessions
Public-to-private network traffic
DMZ-to-public web access attempts
Private-to-DMZ control requests

question: What is a defining trait of an application gateway firewall?
choices: It uses only MAC address filtering and routing tables
It acts as a proxy between client and server
It permits all incoming sessions automatically
It cannot inspect application-layer communications
It depends exclusively on hardware acceleration modules

question: What is the core idea behind zone-based policy firewalls (ZPFs)?
choices: Allow all interzone traffic by default
Depend on hardware routing tables exclusively
Route traffic using static layer-3 entries
Group interfaces into zones for policy control
Filter packets by MAC address for each subnet

question: Which ZPF configuration rule is correct?
choices: Traffic between unzoned interfaces is blocked automatically
All ICMP traffic is always inspected regardless of policy
An interface can’t be in more than one zone
Zone membership instantly secures routing updates between neighbors
Classic and Zone firewall can share a single interface

question: Why is a zone-pair created in ZPF?
choices: To back up policies to external configuration servers
To create logical tunnels for IPsec traffic only
To apply QoS shaping between VLANs
To define source, destination, and policy
To configure static routes for secure zones

question: What occurs when 'zone-member security' is applied too early?
choices: All self-zone flows are mirrored to NMS for diagnostics
Transit traffic is dropped
Interfaces are automatically renamed to temporary zones
The router blocks DNS and DHCP queries until reset
The configuration reverts to legacy Classic Firewall mode

question: If one interface is zoned and the other is not, what happens?
choices: The router passes only ICMP packets for troubleshooting
The connection retries until a default policy is attached
The router inspects and logs the event to syslog automatically
The interface is temporarily moved to a quarantine zone
The traffic is dropped

question: Traffic between a zoned and unzoned interface will be:
choices: Passed with default tracking enabled
Deferred until router reload or policy merge
Accepted only if the ACL includes a permit any-any rule
Forwarded via dynamic service chaining inspection
Dropped

question: Which order correctly builds a ZPF?
choices: Assign interfaces first → Apply NAT → Create class maps → Define zones
Create zones → Class-map → Policy-map → Zonepair → Interfaces
Create global objects → Enable dynamic DNS inspection → Define pairs
Configure ACLs → Verify routing → Attach policies to sub-interfaces
Set up QoS queues before adding inspection and NAT filters

question: Which language defines traffic policies in a ZPF?
choices: Cisco Common Classification Policy Language
Dynamic Security Policy Definition Framework
Cisco Adaptive Security Scripting Engine
Unified Access and Control Expression Protocol for devices
Extended Network Traffic Policy Syntax Interface
